awd_titl_txt: EAGER: Exploring Trade-offs in Cyber Offense and Defense Through the Lenses of Computer and Political Science
awd_abstract_narration:
This project examines the trade-offs governments face between engaging in cyber offense and defense. Governments may exploit a somewhat less secure Internet to gain intelligence and strategic advantage. But a more secure Internet encourages more participation online and reduces citizens' exposure to cybercrime. Thus governments face a difficult dilemma: Should they forego potentially useful cyber operations and work on strengthening the Internet in order to provide a global good? To answer this question, this project aims to construct a taxonomy of offensive and defensive cyber operations, describing the range of attack options and the possible collateral damage they may cause. The project's findings may benefit U.S. national security by giving policymakers a way of assessing the value of offensive cyber operations against the unintended consequences.

Specifically, the proposed research project has three related components: The first component is a summary and assessment of different approaches to offensive and defensive cyber operations and classes of vulnerabilities. The second is an examination of the suitability of two political science theories to the debate over cybersecurity policy: hegemonic stability theory and offense-defense theory. To evaluate these theories in the cyber context, the researchers conduct qualitative and quantitative analysis of historical Internet resiliency, retrospective accounting of prior cyber operations, structured controlled comparative analyses, and counterfactual analyses of past operations. The third part of the project uses the foregoing analysis to develop guidelines for policymakers and intelligence organizations about when to disclose or stockpile vulnerabilities, and how to choose among several different strategies available to balance offense and defense. This project has the potential to transform how we understand the international politics of cybersecurity. It examines cyber warfare trade-offs by testing established political science theories with rigorous computer science analysis. This approach creates an opportunity for reaching an important theoretical breakthrough by deriving parsimonious measures of internet resilience and the offense-defense balance in cyberspace.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to develop and test new measures of internet resilience in a way that combined political science and computer science. The investigators developed five new technical and political measures to examine the consequences of high-profile offensive cyber operations. They used these measures to provide a framework for researchers to describe and evaluate the relative resilience or fragility of the internet. The measures are:

1. User responses. We examined whether and how users changed behavior after revelations of significant cyber attacks and other news of incidents that in theory threatened the security of cyberspace and the integrity of online communications.

2. Firm responses.  We examined whether and how firms changed their business practices. 

3. Political responses. We examined whether hand how states changed their approach to national cybersecurity policy, as well as whether they became less willing to cooperate with states who were suspected of launching offensive cyber operations.

4. Incident responses. We examined how quickly and effectively private and public sector actors were able to recover. Examples include the duration of effects of  denial of service attacks, as well as the rapidity of responses to BGP outages.

5. Infrastructure responses. Finally, we examined the nature of changes to the Information Communication Technology infrastructure. Examples include noticeable changes to industrial control systems, and increasing use of encrypted communications.

By combining these measures we were able to design a framework capturing both the political and technical issues that describe the underlying strengths and weaknesses of the internet. The framework is useful for computer scientists, international security specialists, and international political economists.  It provides a broader understanding of the nature and effects of offensive cyber operations.

It also provides important insights for public policy analysts and policymakers. The results of our analysis inform basic questions about whether the United States needs to play a stronger role in internet governance. Our initial findings suggest that the system is more resilient than some have claimed. If it proves to be largely self-sustaining then the United States need not play a central role in internet governance.  The project also speaks to the ongoing policy debate about whether to pursue offensive cyber operations, even at the risk of undermining cybersecurity. Our findings suggest that in many cases the spillover effects, while real, are manageable. 

 Our research on the topic is continuing. We plan on presenting and publishing research based on the project next year. In addition, of the investigators (Rovner) will be offering a new undergraduate course on cybersecurity next year. Inspired by this collaboration, he is teaming up with a computer scientist to teach the course.
